com.gaurav.tree
Interface Tree<E>

Type Parameters:
E - object type contained in the tree
All Superinterfaces:
java.util.Collection<E>, java.lang.Iterable<E>
All Known Subinterfaces:
NumberedTree<E>
All Known Implementing Classes:
ArrayListTree, BinarySearchTree, BinaryTree, KAryTree
public interface Tree<E>
extends java.util.Collection<E>

The tree is a general interface for all tree types and their implementations. It extends Collection and thus all its methods.
Collection::add(Object) and Collection::addAll(Collection c) methods always adds the first element as root and later ones as children of the root. It is better to use methods of Tree::add(E, E) and Tree::add(E, Collection<E> c) as give better control on the tree structure.
This interface doesn't guarantee any order to be maintained among the children of the tree. All the elements in the tree are guaranteed to be unique.
Null elements are not allowed in the tree.

Author:
Gaurav Saxena

Method Detail

add

boolean add(E parent,
            E child)
            throws NodeNotFoundException
In case an equal object is already present in the tree then the method returns false and the original object is not replaced.

Parameters:
parent - object to which child object needs to be added. Parent is allowed to be null only when there are no other nodes present in the tree. In that case, the child will be added as root
child - object
Returns:
true if parent was found and child is not already in the tree, otherwise false
Throws:
NodeNotFoundException - if parent is not found

addAll

boolean addAll(E parent,
               java.util.Collection<? extends E> c)
Uses add(E parent, E e) to add all the objects present in the collection

Parameters:
parent - object to which child object needs to be added. Parent is allowed to be null only when there are no other nodes present in the tree. In that case, the child will be added as root
c - collection of children to be added to parent
Returns:
true if collection changed as a result of the operation, otherwise false

depth

int depth()
Returns:
depth of the tree i.e. the length of the path which has maximum number of nodes

inorderOrderTraversal

java.util.Collection<E> inorderOrderTraversal()
Returns:
collection of children arranged as inorderOrderTraversal of underlying tree. In order traversal publishes children.size / 2 first and then the node and then nodes from children.size / 2 + 1 to children.size

isAncestor

boolean isAncestor(E node,
                   E child)
                   throws NodeNotFoundException
Finds if the given node is an ancestor of the child node.

Parameters:
node -
child -
Returns:
true if any of the parent of child is equal to node, false otherwise. if node and child node are equal to each other then it returns false
Throws:
NodeNotFoundException

                     E node)
                     throws NodeNotFoundException
Finds if the given node is a descendant of the parent node

Parameters:
node -
parent -
Returns:
true if any of the node belongs to the tree rooted at parent, false otherwise. if node and child node are equal to each other then it returns false
Throws:
NodeNotFoundException

Returns:
all the leaves of the tree i.e. those nodes which do not have children
